keywords.indexterm: page designer design, xsp code, embedded code

conbody.p:
The Page Designer provides several different views of a diagram. These views are read-only:
Design
XSP code (read-only)

section.title: Design view
section.p: The design view is the principal view within the Page Designer. This is the view that is activated when a page is first opened. It provides a Palette menu, which lets you build pages or modules. Additionally, items can be dragged and dropped directly into the design view, either from the DS Navigator view pane or from the Domain outline.

There are several differences between the design view and the final Triple'A Plus page, which are deliberate and are aimed at making the creation of pages simpler:
A space between each widget. This lets you easily add new widgets between existing widgets.
Many of the widgets, which act as containers, have a border (typically grey) that outlines them. This border does not appear in the running application.
Non-visual widgets, such as table columns and hidden fields, are presented in the design view so that their properties can be modified.
Included fragments and modules are greyed-out. This makes it clear that the displayed widgets are from another file and cannot be modified directly within this one.

section.title: XSP code view
section.p: For modules and pages, the XSP code view provides an exact image of the XSP code that is generated by the code generator. This lets technical developers who are experienced with Triple'A Plus understand exactly what code will be generated.

When fragments are included in modules, some of the information that is used to generate the fragment's XSP code is stored in the include widget that contains it (for example, the Bean Prefix property). In other words, the code that is generated for a fragment depends on the context in which it is used. The XSP code view, therefore, is not always a faithful representation of how the fragment will be generated when it is included in a module. However, visualizing the XSP code of the module that contains a fragment is always 100% correct.
The XSP code view is read-only. If the page requires XSP code that cannot be created by the Page Designer, a code widget must be added to a page and the embedded code view can be used.
